qas.question: What language lacks gendered nouns and pronouns?
In the nominative, genitive, partitive, illative, inessive, elative, allative, adessive, ablative, translative cases what always agrees with the noun in number and case?
What language relies on gendered nouns and pronouns?
In nominative cases what never agrees with the noun in number and case?
What is "a yellow house" in Finnish?
How many cases to verbs decline?

context: In <a0_0><b2_0>Estonian<b2_0/><a0_0/>, nouns and pronouns do not have grammatical gender, but nouns and <a1_0>adjectives<a1_0/> decline in <b5_0>fourteen<b5_0/> cases: nominative, genitive, partitive, illative, inessive, elative, allative, adessive, ablative, translative, terminative, essive, abessive, and comitative, with the case and number of the <b3_0>adjective<b3_0/>(s) always agreeing with that of the noun (except in the terminative, essive, abessive and comitative, where there is agreement only for the number, the adjective being in the genitive form). Thus the illative for <b4_0>kollane maja<b4_0/> ("a yellow house") is kollasesse majja ("into a yellow house"), but the terminative is kollase majani ("as far as a yellow house"). With respect to the Proto-Finnic language, elision has occurred; thus, the actual case marker may be absent, but the stem is changed, cf. maja – majja and the Pohjanmaa dialect of Finnish maja – majahan.
